review.title: Anomaly Detection with the Voronoi Diagram Evolutionary Algorithm
review.abstract: This paper presents the Voronoi diagram-based evolutionary algorithm (VorEAl). VorEAl partitions input space in abnormal/normal subsets using Voronoi diagrams. Diagrams are evolved using a multi-objective bio-inspired approach in order to conjointly optimize classification metrics while also being able to represent areas of the data space that are not present in the training dataset. As part of the paper VorEAl is experimentally validated and contrasted with similar approaches.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Anomalous data transmission is an important issue of computer network security. Intrusion Detection Systems (IDSs) [9] have proposed to address this problem. They are designed to protect a network by providing a line of defense capable of detecting and responding to network attacks. Two main approaches are used in building an IDS: i) abuse-based and ii) anomaly-based detection. While the former focuses on detecting attacks that follow a known pattern or signature, the latter is interested in developing a model that represents the normal behavior of the system, while all derived activities are anomalous or intrusions. As a result, the anomaly detection has gained increasing attention in the recent past. Anomaly detection has been tackled with various approaches (see [2] for a survey.

sections.heading: 2 Foundations
sections.text: In this context, AISs have attracted attention because they have an analogy to the biological immune system. They are particularly attractive for abnormal recognition problems because they are particularly suitable to be applied in the context of abnormal body cells. In order to enhance the performance of AISs, it is necessary to use algorithms that have a strong representational capacity.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion and conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced VorEAl, a multi-objective evolutionary algorithm based on Voronoi diagrams for representation. VorEAl was developed with the problem of detecting anomalies in mind, and the experimental results obtained in this work indicate that this is a promising direction of work, but there are many areas that should be further investigated and explored. From an algorithmic point of view, we should explore other classification goals (metrics). It is important to try other multi-objective fitness mappings, such as those based on multi-objective performance indicators or reference points. The latter approach is of particular interest because, as already mentioned, we have an a priori known ideal solution that can be used to orientate the search. In parallel, work should be undertaken to understand and reduce the computational complexity of the algorithm. In this direction, we are already working on calculating the cost of the approximation of the objective to reduce the cost of the objective algorithm.
